title: 108_hr332
content: The Act is titled the "National Reconstruction Study Area Act" and includes findings. Congress finds that during the Reconstruction Era, significant events occurred in the United States, including the adoption of amendments ending slavery and guaranteeing civil and voting rights. Beaufort, South Carolina, and the surrounding sea islands have historical and archaeological sites related to this era, offering a unique opportunity for preservation and interpretation. The first African-Americans to hear the Emancipation Proclamation gathered at the Old Fort Plantation on January 1, 1863. The Penn School on St. Helena Island, South Carolina, was the first educational experiment of the Reconstruction Era and remains a significant African-American cultural and educational institution in the United States. The Freedmen's Bureau in Beaufort College was the chief policy arm of the Federal Government for matters related to emancipated slaves during the Reconstruction Era. Beaufort County, South Carolina, and the surrounding sea islands have many other historic buildings and archaeological sites. Archaeological sites in South Carolina include buildings and sites associated with Robert Smalls, a former slave who became a Union hero and later represented the state in the House of Representatives during the Reconstruction Era. Other sites include the first Freedmen's Village of Mitchellville, Camp Sexton where the first African-American regiment was mustered, and Penn School and Beaufort College. The National Park System lacks a park dedicated to the Reconstruction Era, a crucial period of cultural and political division in the US. Understanding this complex history and its ongoing impact is essential. The National Park System lacks a park dedicated to the Reconstruction Era, a crucial period of cultural and political division in the US. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "Secretary" in this Act refers to the Secretary of the Interior, acting through the Director of the National Park Service. The "study area" includes historical sites in the historic district of Beaufort, South Carolina, related to the Reconstruction Era, such as the Penn School, Old Fort Plantation, Freedmen's Bureau in Beaufort College, and First Freedmen's Village of Mitchellville on Hilton Head Island. The study area includes historic buildings and archaeological sites associated with Robert Smalls, the Beaufort Arsenal, and other significant sites related to the Reconstruction Era in Beaufort, South Carolina. The Secretary will conduct a study to assess the suitability of designating the study area as a National Park unit. The study will be done in accordance with applicable law. Once completed, a report will be submitted to the House Committee on Resources and the Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources detailing the findings, conclusions, and recommendations.
